questions.text: A young male patient presented with recurrent episodes of acute neurologic dysfunction, cognitive changes, muscle weakness, and lactic acidosis. There is a family history of similar conditions depicted in the pedigree chart below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) MELAS

 

Explanation:

MELAS-Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes:

  • MELAS follows a unique non-Mendelian pattern of inheritance called maternal inheritance, as mitochondrial DNA is derived entirely from the ovum.
  • Affected mothers and daughters transmit the disease to both male and female children, whereas the affected sons don't transmit the affected DNA. (Mother to all, Father to none.)
  • The most common mitochondrial disease is MELAS.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of a 5-year-old child with hyperphagia, delayed milestones, and growth retardation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Prader-Willi syndrome

 

Explanation:

Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) affects the SNORP gene on chromosome 15q.

  • PWS is due to paternal deletion and maternal imprinting of the given gene.
  • Subset of PWS can also occur due to maternal disomy
  • Clinical features:
    • Mental retardation (Delayed milestones)
    • Short stature
    • Hypotonia
    • Obesity (Due to increased levels of ghrelin)
      • Ghrelin is an appetite-stimulating hormone that leads to overeating and finally obesity.

Angelman syndrome (Option A) has a similar genetic basis to PWS but is caused by absent maternal expression of 15q11-q13, while the paternal allele is imprinted.

questions.text: Which of the following does not show the same pattern of inheritance as Leber hereditary optic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fragile-X syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • Fragile-X syndrome shows X-linked Recessive > X-linked dominant inheritance.
  •  Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is characterized by permanent loss of vision in young men due to progressive, bilateral optic neuropathy.
  • LHON demonstrates mitochondrial inheritance.

 

Some other examples of mitochondrial inheritance disorders are:

  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)/ Kearns-Sayre syndrome (KSS)
  • Leigh syndrome
  • Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS) (Option B ruled out)
  • Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers (MERRF) (Option A ruled out)
  • Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) (Option D ruled out)
  • Primary coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) deficiency

questions.text:
Match the following

 


	
		
			
			Disease 
			
			
			Trinucleotide repeats 
			
		
		
			
			a. Fragile X syndrome
			
			
			1. CAG
			
		
		
			
			b. Friedreich ataxia
			
			
			2. CTG
			
		
		
			
			c. Myotonic dystrophy
			
			
			3. GAA
			
		
		
			
			d. Huntington disease
			
			
			4. CGG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1

 

Explanation:

The below-mentioned disorders are trinucleotide repeat disorders where there is excessive repetition of trinucleotides.

  • In Introns/ Non coding region:
    • Fragile X syndrome - CGG
    • Friedreich ataxia - GAA
    • Myotonic dystrophy -CTG

 

  • In Exons/ Coding region:
    • Huntington's disease - CAG (Mnemonic- Hunter in a Cage)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with brief, abrupt, involuntary movements of his arms and face for the last 2 months. A history of Huntington's disease in his father, who was diagnosed at 40 years of age and passed away at the age of 50, is found. What is the mechanism behind this patient’s earlier presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anticipation

 

Explanation:

  • HD is a CAG trinucleotide repeat disorder, seen in the axon region of a gene present on chromosome 4.
  • HD is characterised by the Anticipation/Sherman Paradox.
  • The number of repeats increases with every generation, leading to early and more severe presentation in the next generation.
  • HD features psychiatric disturbances and choreoathetosis early on, with cognitive disturbance and death later.

Examples of diseases showing anticipation include:

Autosomal Dominant

Autosomal Recessive
  • Multiple spinocerebellar ataxias
  • Huntington’s disease – CAG repeats
  • Myotonic dystrophy – CTG
  • Congenital dyskeratosis – TTAGGG (telomere repeating sequence)

Friedreich’s ataxia – GAA

X-linked

Fragile X Syndrome – CGG

Others
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Behcet’s disease


Mosaicism (Option B) refers to the presence of multiple genetically different cell lines in the same individual.

Imprinting (Option C) refers to a gene silencing.

Non-penetrance (Option D): It means that the Gene is received from parents but no symptoms are seen in patient.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician’s office for evaluation of developmental delay and seizures. She is very jovial, has microcephaly and is diagnosed with happy puppet syndrome. What is the genetic basis for this child’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Imprinting

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario likely describes Angelman syndrome.

  • Classical symptom of Angelman syndrome: Happy puppet syndrome (inappropriate laughter).

2 main disorders of genomic imprinting:

  1. Angelman syndrome (AS):  Paternal 15q11-q13 region is imprinted, while the maternal region is deleted
  2. Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS): Paternal deletion and maternal imprinting on chromosome 15.

questions.text: Which of the following explains a single mutant gene leading to different end effects in sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Pleiotropy

 

Explanation:

A single mutant gene leading to many end effects is called pleiotropism, whereas mutations at several genetic loci producing a similar phenotypic effect are called genetic heterogeneity.

  • Sickle cell anemia is an example of pleiotropy with a single gene mutation causing multiple physical effects:
    • Mutation at beta-7 position: Glutamic acid is replaced by valine.
    • The mutation produces hemoglobin S (HbS), which makes red blood cells prone to hemolysis.
    • Additionally, it can lead to complications like splenic fibrosis, organ infarcts, and bone pains.

questions.text: A group of researchers studying genetic material noticed the presence of both wild-type and mutated mitochondrial genomes in different mitochondria of the same cells. What does this finding indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Heteroplasmy

 

Explanation:

The presence of both wild-type and mutated mitochondrial genomes in different mitochondria of the same cell is called heteroplasmy.

  • A minimum number of mutant mtDNAs must be present in a cell to give rise to a disease.
  • This is called the “threshold effect.”

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with intentional tremors, cerebellar ataxia, and intellectual disability. His father had similar symptoms at 60 and died due to aortic dissection. The patient's son started showing tremors and has an intellectual disability and aggressive behavior. Additionally males of the family have large ears and mandibles. What condition is most likely affecting him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fragile X syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • Fragile X Syndrome (FXS) results from CGG trinucleotide repeat disorder.
    • CGG repeats <55: Normal individual
    • CGG repeats are between 55-200: Fragile X–-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome
    • CGG repeats >200: Fragile X syndrome

Fragile X syndrome: 

  • A very common cause of intellectual disability which is seen in all members of the family.
  • IQ = 20-60
  • Mostly males are affected because it is an X-linked recessive (XLR) disorder. Females mostly are carriers.
  • Physical phenotype: Includes a long face with a large mandible, large ears, and macroorchidism (enlarged testicles).
  • Investigation of choice: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
  • If PCR fails then we go for Southern blotting.

questions.text: A one-month-old infant presents with developmental delays and physical features such as a prominent occiput, low-set ears, clenched hands with overlapping fingers, and a small mouth with a protruding tongue. Heart murmurs and rocker-bottom foot deformity are also noted. Which syndrome is the most likely cause of these features?
questions.solution:
Correct option: D) Edward syndrome

 

Explanation:

Edward syndrome is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18- Trisomy 18.

On USG: Strawberry skull is seen: Prominent occiput and small chin.

Features:

  • Low birth weight
  • Clenched fists with overlapping fingers
  • Rocker-bottom feet (seen in trisomy 18 and trisomy 13)
  • Microcephaly
  • Micrognathia
  • Macroglosia (Big protruding tongue)
  • Cardiac and renal malformations
  • Mental retardation

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for delayed milestones. Upon examination, the pediatrician notices several physical features, including upward-slanting eyes, a flat facial profile, a protruding tongue, and a single palmar crease. Which type of inheritance is definitely not present in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct option: D) Autosomal recessive inheritance

Explanation:

The clinical features are indicative of Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), which is not inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Features:

  • Mongoloid facies: Upward slanting of eyes (because of oblique palpebral fissure) and flat facial profile (because of nasal hypoplasia)
  • Macroglossia (Protruding tongue)
  • Simian crease (single palmar crease)

Modes of inheritance of Down syndrome are as follows:

  • Meiotic Nondisjunction of chromosome 21 (95%) (Option A): The nondisjunction occurs in the Ovum or in mother's germ cells.
  • Robertsonian Translocation (4%) (Option B): t(22,14) in mother.
  • Mitotic Nondisjunction (1%) (Option C): This leads to mosaicism.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child has recently passed away after a long ICU stay. Examination reveals microphthalmia and microcephaly. Other known diagnoses included ventricular septal defect, polycystic kidney disease, and omphalocele at birth. What is the chromosome involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chromosome 13

 

Explanation:

The given scenario describes Patau syndrome or Trisomy 13.

Clinical features and associations include

  • Rocker-bottom feet (Seen in both trisomy 13 and trisomy 18)
  • Severe intellectual disability
  • Keyhole/ Coloboma (eyes)
  • Microphthalmia, microcephaly, holoprosencephaly
  • Cleft lip/palate
  • Polydactyly
  • Congenital heart disease: PDA (Patent Ductus Arteriosus) or VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect)
  • Renal defects-Polycystic kidney disease
  • Umbilical hernia,Omphalocele

 

Trisomy 18 is Edward syndrome: Clinical features include a prominent occiput (Strawberry skull) and rocker-bottom feet (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 30-year-old tall male patient presents to the clinic for fertility treatment. He undergoes testing and is found to have low sperm counts. He has a history of diabetes, and a physical examination reveals gynecomastia, small testes, and minimal facial and body hair. What chromosomal abnormality is most likely causing this condition in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 47,XXY

 

Explanation:

Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is male hypogonadism with an extra X chromosome.

Clinical features:

  • Initially, the gonads are testes, but because of an extraX chromosome, the testes stay underdeveloped and small (hypogonadism).
  • Low sperm counts
  • Secondary sexual characteristics also not developed, like no facial hair.
  • Gynecomastia due to an extra X chromosome.

Hormonal profile: Low serum testosterone levels leading to high LH and FSH levels.

Most common cancer risk: Male breast cancer

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents to the clinic due to the concern that she hasn't started menstruating yet. The girl has a short stature and a webbed neck. Physical examination reveals a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Turner syndrome

Explanation:

 The scenario is diagnosed as Turner syndrome.

  • Genotype: 45 XO
  • Phenotype: Female
  • Improper breast development leading to widely spaced nipples
  • Improper ovarian development: Female presents with streak ovaries and primary amenorrhea (patient will not attain menarche).
  •  Physical symptoms: Short stature and webbed neck
  • Cardiac anomalies: Bicuspid aortic valve and Coarctation of aorta.
  • Usually, IQ is normal.

The image below shows karyotyping in Turner syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with tall stature and long limbs, along with a history of frequent joint dislocations. Upon physical examination, he exhibits long fingers ,sunken chest, and an echocardiogram shows a dilated aortic root. Considering these clinical features, which of the following genes are commonly mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) FBN 1

Explanation:

A 15-year-old boy presents with tall stature, long limbs, joint dislocations, long fingers, a sunken chest, and a dilated aortic root on echocardiogram; these features are consistent with Marfan syndrome, which is commonly caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene

  • An autosomal dominant disorder due to a mutation in the Fibrillin (FBN) 1 Gene on chromosome 15.

Clinical Features:

 

Marfan Disease

The most common Clinical Manifestation is Skeletal Abnormalities.
  • Mitral Valve Prolapse (Most common Cardiac abnormality)
  • Aortic Dissection (Most common cause of death)
  • Retinal Detachment (eye problem)
  • Freely movable Joint (most common Thumb joint)
  • Arachnodactyly (long fingers, spider fingers), High Arched Palate
  • Nine Feet Tall, Pigeon chest (defect in sternum)
  • Dislocation of the lens (Ectopia Lentis- Direction of dislocation is Supero Temporal)

Steinberg Sign- Positive if the thumb tip extends beyond the palm when folded into a closed fist

Walker Sign- Positive if the thumb and fifth finger overlap when you grip your wrist with the opposite hand
